Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Characterization of a modern East African ecosystem to inform reconstructions of hominin diet

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Diet is an important factor in studies of human evolution because it is linked to behavior, morphology, and ecology. This doctoral dissertation project seeks to increase our understanding of the diets of early human ancestors through analysis of modern East African ecosystems. The student co-PI will evaluate the nutritional and mechanical properties of dominant savanna and wetland plants, in addition to commonly eaten and avoided baboon foods, across gradients of seasonal and microhabitat variability. Previous work has shed light on broad habitat and food preferences of early humans, and this project's focus on seasonality and microhabitat will provide important new data to augment past studies. This project will support student and research assistant training in ecological field methods, public science outreach activities designed to reach students from groups underrepresented in STEM fields, and conservation efforts at the research site.

This project will address the lack of ecological data currently available for reconstructing diet in Plio-Pleistocene hominins by studying the mechanical properties of foods that may have been accessible to hominins. The researchers will conduct fieldwork across both the wet and dry seasons in Amboseli National Park, Kenya, a site known for its high microhabitat heterogeneity and large yellow baboon (Papio cynocephalus) populations. They will establish sampling transects in different microhabitats (grassland, wetland, scrubland, etc.) and collect dominant tree, forb, herb, grass, and sedge species in each transect (where applicable). Commonly eaten and avoided baboon foods will also be collected within each transect; baboons are a suitable ecological analogue for early humans because of their wide dietary niche and preference for savanna habitats. A portable mechanical tester will be used on fresh plant material to measure the hardness and toughness of the component parts (root, stem, leaf, etc.) of each sampled species. Once mechanical testing is complete, remaining plant samples will be dried and analyzed for fiber, lignin, fat and oil, protein, and trace metal content. The resulting nutritional and mechanical properties data incorporating both seasonal and microhabitat variability can be used to build predictive models of early human foraging behavior.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Abigale Koppa, a PhD candidate in Ecology and Evolution at Stony Brook University, has nearly completed the research for her doctoral dissertation "Nutritional and Mechanical Properties of East African Savannah Plants," supported by the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant. During the funding period, she made two trips to her fieldsite in Amboseli National Park, Kenya and two trips to the Nutritional and Isotopic Ecology Lab at the University of Colorado Boulder. She is interested in how modern ecological data can inform patterns and trends in the fossil record. More specifically, she studies Kenyan savannah plant foods as a way to evaluate dietary data from fossil human ancestors (hominins). 

Koppa, along with her collaborators Oliver Paine and Jennifer Leichliter from CU Boulder, made two trips to Kenya during the grant period to carry out her dissertation research. The first trip was during the wet season and the second was during the dry season. The team established sampling transects in wetland, woodland, and grassland habitats and collected samples of the most common tree, grass, sedge, and forb species present in each transect. This approach allowed for a thorough analysis of the food landscape of an African savannah, a habitat known to be utlized by hominins.

To evaluate the quality of collected samples, Koppa studied their mechanical and nutritional properties. Mehcnaical properties were measured in the field on fresh samples using a portable mechanical tester, which yielded measures of plant toughness. Remaining samples were then dehydrated, packed, and exported back to the US for nutritional analyses at the Nutritional and Isotopic Ecology Lab at CU Boulder. Koppa carried out protein, fat, fiber, lignin, and ash analyses. The resulting nutritional and mechanical dataset has proven to be a rich source of data on the quality and variability of savannah plant foods.

The data collected for this project have demonstrated a predictive relationship between plant mechanical properties and nutritional quality. They have also contradicted the long-held assumption that savannah grasses are a uniformally low-quality food source. Koppa's dataset can now be used to evaluate certain foods as potentially important hominin resources. Eventually, she hopes to use the data to build models to predict foraging behavior.

These data have already contributed to one peer-reviwed publication and two conferences presentations, with several additional publications close to submission and in prep. Koppa will defend her dissertation in Spring 2019.
